content.user_title: Run Codex CLI for Code Analysis and Refactoring
content.value_statement: Complex code analysis and refactoring tasks require specialized AI models with advanced reasoning capabilities. This skill enables Claude Code to invoke OpenAI Codex CLI, providing access to GPT-5.2 with 76.3% SWE-bench performance for deep code understanding, automated refactoring, and comprehensive software engineering workflows.
actual_capabilities: Invokes OpenAI Codex CLI (codex exec) for code analysis and refactoring tasks
Supports multiple GPT-5.2 model variants including gpt-5.2-max, gpt-5.2, and gpt-5.2-mini
Configures sandbox modes (read-only, workspace-write, danger-full-access) for controlled execution
Manages reasoning effort levels (xhigh, high, medium, low) for different task complexities
Enables session resumption with context preservation across Codex invocations
Filters thinking tokens to manage context window usage during long-running tasks
limitations: Requires Codex CLI v0.57.0 or later installed and configured on the system
Does not include Codex CLI; users must install and configure credentials separately
Cannot execute code directly; Claude invokes the external codex CLI based on skill guidelines
Network access depends on sandbox mode configuration; read-only is the default

faq.question: How do I install and configure the Codex CLI?
faq.answer: Install the Codex CLI following OpenAI's documentation. Verify installation with 'codex --version' and configure credentials. The skill will invoke codex exec commands based on your prompts.

faq.question: What is the difference between sandbox modes?
faq.answer: Read-only limits access to viewing files. Workspace-write permits creating and modifying files in a sandbox. Danger-full-access allows broad system access. Use read-only for analysis by default.

faq.question: How do I resume a Codex session?
faq.answer: Simply say 'codex resume' or ask to continue with the previous session. Claude will use 'codex exec resume --last' with the same model and settings from the original session.

faq.question: What reasoning effort should I use?
faq.answer: Xhigh for ultra-complex problems requiring deep analysis. High for refactoring, security reviews, and performance optimization. Medium for standard coding tasks. Low for quick fixes and formatting.

faq.question: How does the skill handle thinking tokens?
faq.answer: By default, thinking tokens (stderr) are suppressed to save context window space. Ask to see thinking tokens if you need visibility into Codex's internal reasoning process.

faq.question: Can I switch models mid-session?
faq.answer: Within a Codex session, use the /model slash command to switch models. Between sessions, specify the model in your prompt. The skill defaults to gpt-5.2.
